newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - Jan 27.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - S.Korean newspapers - Jan 27.

text.p: The following is a summary of major South Korean political stories in leading newspapers, prepared by Reuters in Seoul. Reuters has not checked the stories and does not guarantee their accuracy. Telephone: (822) 727-5650. Fax: (822) 727-5666.
- Suspicions of illegal financing for Hanbo Steel Co will be thoroughly investigated and the results will be released to the public, an unnamed official at the presidential Blue House said.

- Taiwan newspapers have reported that negotiations with South Korea for resuming air services faced difficulties while economic and trade relations among Taiwan and North Korea would be strengthened.
- President Kim Young-sam and Japan's Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto agreed to resume regular Korea-Japan soccer tournaments starting in May, a foreign ministry official said.

- President Kim expressed explicit displeasure with a Japanese politician's remarks over past misdeeds, while Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto implicitly reiterated Japan's sovereignty claim to the Tokto islets during a summit meeting at Beppu.
- Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro told President Kim Young-sam he shared South Korea's concern over Taiwan's plan to ship nuclear waste to North Korea, foreign policy advisor Ban Ki-moon said.
- Due to Hanbo Steel Co's collapse, it is estimated that the nation's rate of dishonoured bills in January will be the highest since 1982 at possibly over 0.3 percent of total bills.
